III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section Intervention standards and prohibitions
Description (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Recently, Youth A was restrained after he was accused of hitting
another resident. During the restraint, Staff 3 hit Youth A in the
right shoulder or both Staff 2 and Staff 3 were hitting Youth A
throughout the restraint. Youth A was scratched on his right
forearm by Staff 2. The restraint took place in Youth A's room and
there are no cameras in the room.
Investigation Administrator 1 was interviewed via phone on 5/7/2025. She
reported not being aware of the allegations and has had no issues
with Staff 1 nor Staff 2 since being employed at the facility.
Administrator 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/7/2025. He reported receiving no incident reports involving a
restraint of Youth A for the last 3 to 6 months and was surprised
by the allegations. Staff are to notify administration if a restraint
takes place. He also reported Youth A has a history of making
false allegations in an effort to be moved to another placement.
He reported hearing Youth A say that Youth A will call Law
Enforcement and Child Protective Services to get staff fired. He
also reported having no concerns about Staff 2 and Staff 3.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/7/2025. Youth B reported feeling safe and well cared for at the
facility. Youth B also reported staff are very positive and helpful
towards him. Youth B reported Youth A is very aggressive and
struggles to calm himself down once escalated. Youth B also
reported Youth A lies about things and had told Youth B that
Youth A wants to get staff into trouble.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/7/2025. Youth C reported feeling safe and having staff that are
very helpful and caring about Youth C. Youth C also reported staff
are always providing support for him. Youth C reported there have
2

been no restraints with Youth A and Youth A will make up things
about staff.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/7/2025.
Staff 1 is the Family Transition Coordinator at the facility. She
reported this is the first she has heard of the allegations and
believes it occurred last week. She also reported that at the time
of her last meeting with Youth A, Youth A presented as being
upset and wanting to change placements. She reported Youth A
never mentioned Staff 2 or Staff 3 but just wanting to leave and
have a new placement, which she indicated is something Youth A
has a history of doing. Staff 1 also reported Youth A was arguing
with another youth earlier in the day but knew nothing of a
physical fight between Youth A and another youth the day Youth A
was taken to the hospital. She reported never being informed of
Youth A being restrained and that she normally is informed of any
restraints. She also reported an incident report on Youth A was on
4/15/25 and it was because of physical aggression, verbal
aggression, property destruction, and leaving the cottage without
permission. Since that incident report, Youth A received two
incident reports on 4/28/25. The first was for medication refusal
and the second was for leaving the cottage and area without
permission. She reported the program is meeting Youth A’s need
with the exception of family involvement. She also reported the
parents are not making much of an effort to visit as ordered by the
court. The parents are ordered to visit weekly but only manage to
visit once every three weeks.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/14/2025. She reported working the day Youth A was taken to
the hospital by Law Enforcement and Youth A was never
restrained. She also reported Youth A wants a hug from her daily
and Youth A only tries to become aggressive with the other youth.
She reported generally Youth A is only verbally aggressive and
she is able to redirect Youth A. Youth A will become involved in
situations that don’t involve him causing the verbal aggression.
She reported on the day of the Law Enforcement intervention;
Youth A was to return to the cottage after school but went to
another cottage instead. She reported telling Youth A he was not
to be with the older boys and having Youth A tell her staff are too
involved with him as he left the cottage. She also reported staying
in the cottage with the other youth and letting “on-call” know that
Youth A had left the cottage without permission. She reported
another staff was outside of the cottage but was unable to recall
who this staff was. She denied engaging in restraints of youth and
stated, “I don’t put my hands on any of them”. She also reported
3

never observing Youth A being restrained or being restrained by
Staff 3. She reported Staff 3 was not working in the cottage the
day Youth A was taken to the hospital.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/14/2025. Youth A refused to talk about the incident because it
makes him “sad”. Youth A reported the staff at the facility are
“cool” and both Staff 2 and Staff 3 are “the coolest”. Youth A also
reported Staff 2 helps him the most and “cooks the best food of all
time”. Youth A reported Staff 3 loves the youth and takes youth
out for activities. Youth A also reported there is nothing he doesn’t
like about the facility and staff have never made him feel unsafe.
Youth A reported having suicidal thoughts when at the hospital but
since being back at the facility, he is feeling much better. Youth A
reported taking his medication helps and he is now on new
medication. Youth A reported having no knowledge of a restraint
and doesn’t even know what a restraint looks like. Youth A denied
any staff hitting him or scratching him. Youth A reported getting
into fights with other youth but didn’t want to talk about it. Youth A
ended by reporting feeling safe and that staff keep an eye on him.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/14/2025. He reported having no knowledge of a restraint of
Youth A by Staff 2 and Staff 3 and normally staff are to notify
supervisors of restraints. He also reported not being present the
day Youth A was taken to the hospital by Law Enforcement. He
reported another supervisor (unnamed) informed Supervisor 1 that
an incident between two youths occurred, and Youth A was taken
to the hospital. He reported Youth A has a history of injecting
himself into situations that are not involving Youth A thus causing
a situation between Youth A and another youth. When staff inform
Youth A that his input is not needed at the time, Youth A will
become upset and at times Youth A will “blow up” and destroy
things. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A gets inpatient and becomes
very dysregulated when things don’t go Youth A’s way. Once
Youth A calms down, Youth A becomes remorseful and wants to
avoid talking about Youth A’s behaviors.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/14/2025. He reported not working the shift when Youth A went
to the hospital but came in later that day. He also reported there
have been no restraints on any youth in months. He reported
Youth A will intervene when Staff 2 is speaking to another youth
and when asked to stop becomes upset. When Youth A can’t get
his way or is held accountable, Youth A becomes dysregulated.
Staff 3 also reported Youth A normally confronts other youth or
4

female staff when dysregulated and will blame others if losing
privileges. He reported never witnessing Staff 2 restrain, hit or
scratch a youth and Staff 2 is able to de-escalate Youth A
verbally. Staff 3 also reported Youth A has made statements of
“I’m going to get you fired” when angry and upset.
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 5/23/2025. She
reported having nothing more to add to the allegations but also
reported wondering how honest Youth A was when telling her
about the allegations. She reported believing Youth A has a
history of making false allegations when held accountable and
Youth A became angry when Youth A changed the story, and she
called him “out on it”. She reported Youth A ran to staff, crying and
seeking a hug when staff came to pick Youth A up.
Documents Reviewed:
Methodist Children’s Home Society Residential Treatment
Overview Policy II.E.4 Crisis Prevention Institution –
Nonviolent Crisis Intervention dated 9/1/2024. This policy
outlines staff must only use approved Crisis Prevention Institute
(CPI) techniques when using a restraint with youth. It is also
documented that the only reason staff can restraint youth is for
physical aggression towards another youth or staff, physical
aggression towards themselves, and gross property destruction
that may result in a person being harmed. This document also
outlines that “staff are not permitted to hit, kick, or strike a youth at
any time”.
Methodist Children’s Home Society Residential Treatment
Overview Policy II.E.5 Crisis Situation for CPI dated 9/1/2024.
This document outlines that staff are to use the CPI techniques
and engage in yearly training. It is also documented staff are to
utilize the appropriate techniques to match the level of
dysregulation the youth is presenting at the time. CPI has a
breakdown of intervention techniques for each level of a youth’s
dysregulation.
Methodist Children’s Home Society Residential Treatment
Overview Policy II.E.13 Physical Intervention dated 9/1/2024.
This document outlines that staff should only use physical
intervention as a “last resort” It is also documented staff are to use
a variety of behavior management and crisis intervention
techniques including, relationship building, managing the
environment, active listening, crisis co-regulation, emotional first
aid, and other early intervention to de-escalate the situation.
5

Methodist Children’s Home Society Residential Treatment
Overview Policy I.D.6 Reporting and Documenting Critical
Incidents dated 12/1/2024. This document outlines the events in
which staff must complete incident reports. This list of events
includes aggressive behaviors that result in physical management.
Staff are required to complete the incident report in its entirety by
the end of their shift and turn the incident report into the
designated box within the cottage.
Methodist Children’s Home Society Incident Reports for
Youth A over the past few months.
• 3/4/25 (physical aggression, property destruction, disruptive
behavior, and leaving without permission),
• 3/15/25 (physical aggression).
• 3/29/25 (AWOL),
• 4/1/25 (property destruction).
• 4/1/25 (AWOL, property destruction, destructive behavior,
suicide threats/ideation, physical aggression, and verbal
aggression).
• 4/1/25 (refused medication).
• 4/1/25 (leaving area, police contact, and allegations on
staff).
Incident reports dated the day of the alleged inappropriate
restraint:
Methodist Children’s Home Society Incident Report dated
4/28/25. This document indicates this involved only Youth A and
took place at 3:12 pm in the Stoner Cottage. It is documented that
Youth A refused to follow staff’s directions by walking out of the
cottage without permission. Staff counseled Youth A on behavior
choices as part of the debriefing. This document was written by
Staff 2.
Methodist Children’s Home Society Incident Report dated
4/28/25. This document indicates this involved only Youth A and
took place at 8:00 am in the Stoner Cottage. It is documented that
Youth A refused medication because medication makes Youth A
sleepy. This document was written by Staff 4.
Methodist Children’s Home Society Incident Report dated
4/28/25. This document indicates this involved only Youth A and
took place at 6:15 pm in the Stoner Cottage. It is documented that
Staff 5 caught up with Youth A as Youth A was walking away from
6

the Stoner Cottage. Youth A was upset and stated Youth A
wanted to kill self and staff. Youth A was then taken to the
hospital. It is documented Youth A told the Complainant at the
hospital that everyone in Stoner Cottage yells, curses, and makes
threats to beat up Youth A. This document was written by Staff 5.
Walk-through:
A walk-through was completed at the facility. The facility is well
furnished and maintained. Youth A’s bedroom was also well
furnished, maintained and clean.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance with evidence by interviews with
staff, youth, and documents reviews. A review of the incident
reports for Youth A provided no evidence of Youth A being
restrained or harmed by staff in the past several months since
staff reported such and no incident reports of a restraint exist. All
staff interviewed reported no restraint occurred and Youth A
reported no restraint occurred.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
